messageBody:
I know this may be getting annoying, but I'm a bit of an alphabet-
phile, so I'm sure you'll all bear with me. I also know that this is
a forum for the read alphabet, so I'll be keeping my clearscript
correspondance to email from here on out, but there are some general
things that I wanted to bring to light here.

------

I still think the vowels should be moved to the writing line. This
way, they are actually sharply differentiated against the rest of the
letters by their height. Perhaps they could all be moved to the
upper parallel to make them sort of floaty (as vowels tend to be),
but I'll leave that to you.

Also, the voiced characters as descenders are going to make for some
very messy writing & I will explain why:

In english, you will note that we have very few descending letters:
lowercase g,j,p,q,and y only. These are because descenders tend to
clutter, clump and generally make unreadable whatever is directly
below them. You will also note that, in response to this, the
descenders we DO have are comparatively simple and uncluttered; they
are straight and thin or slightly curved and thin. In your scheme,
you will have large portions of characters resting below the writing
line, and this will virtually necessitate a double-spaced and
inefficient format. Other languages have solved (or never
encountered) the problem of descenders by simply making one square
writing line (Chinese, Japanese, Korean for instance). I would
suggest the same to you. Once again, I would argue that most people
do not really make the IPA distinctions (in this case between voiced
and unvoiced). HowEVER, people ARE able to think of a relation
between sounds, so your scheme of inversing letters to denote
voiced/unvoiced pairs is still a good one and will help in
memorization.

If you still wish to retain some immediately definining character
between voiced and unvoiced, perhaps a little tweaking is in order?
Maybe make all unvoiced characters start in the lower right quadrant
and all voiced ones in the upper right? Those exceptions to pairs
could start anywhere else. These are of course just random ideas to
let you know directions you could take.

I personally think it would be fine without such distinctions aside
from the inverting. When creating a new alphabet, it is often easy
to err on the side of either mnemonics, readability or writing speed,
whilst throwing one or both of the others out of balance. In the
case of quickscript, for instance, I believe it is imbalanced
slightly on the side writing speed against mnemonics and
readability. Now, I know I'll probably catch some flak for saying
that here, but it's true. This is not to say that Quickscript needs
to be changed. Far from it. In fact, I still love it. I'm just
pointing out some things for perspective. English as-is is
unbalanced against mnemonics, and clearscript (even without
descenders) has one-up in this instance.

In making a usable alphabet, it's all about what's important to you
and about considering who you're creating for. Keep in mind that
most alphabet learning is done by straight memorization anyway and
has been for millenia. As well, if you are to replace Traditional
Orthography, you're going to need to provide a lot of advantage with
little or no disadvantage in these three categories. Further
difficulty arises in getting someone to use your alphabet when they
already have a native one.

Sound tough?

It IS.

Good luck. I'll be around for any input or bitching you may want.
